comments:
This only occurs in 1.0.2 development.  Steps to reproduce:

-Create a JPA project with persistence.xml and orm.xml.
-Edit either XML file once and save the changes (not sure if this step is necessary)
-Edit again and discard the changes by closing the editor
-Open this file and edit.  Every keystroke will cause an NPE.

Below are the associated stack traces, beginning with the scenario described above:

A structured model client, EMF2DOMSSEAdapter(persistence-unit,null) threw following exception during adapter notification (CONTENT_CHANGED )

The "root" cause of this sort of bug is usually a "dangling model" somewhere that has not been released ... and/or some adapters are "left around" listening to things but the adapters are no longer connected up correctly to a correct model. 

Similar to when listeners are added to something, but never removed (they still receive notification, but the thing it was expecting to operate on is no longer around.) 

You probably already knew that, but thought I'd comment incase it helps (it would not fix the bug, for example, just to add null checks to avoid the NPE's ... there'd likely be tons of memory being leaked, if if no NPE's).

(Not sure why I didn't try this first, but ...)

This exception also happens when you follow the exact same steps for an EJB project (ejb-jar.xml) and Connector project (ra.xml) and I assume for all other EMF translator modeled resources.

So I'm reassigning to Web Tools.

Note 1:  This also occurs in the development stream (3.0)

Note 2:  It looks like the Project Explorer content be used (or at least loaded) while reproducing this bug.  It's apparent that another persistent user of the EMF model (whether it's Project Explorer content, or JPA project content, etc.) be present to show this behavior.
This appears to be a regression from 2.0.
